channel.title: I need some suggestions
channel.description:
I want to begin coding my own rsps. I've done nothing more than setting up an already-made server and got it running. Now I want to see what would be a good starting point for creating a wonderful server.
I would like to know the following things: What's a good source to start with? What are some "must-study" tutorials found on this website? What should I start coding first? Can I code offline, then release the update once I'm online?
I'm on a Mac. OSX 10.8.

item.title: I need some suggestions
item.dc:creator: @eyeownyew Eyeownyew
item.description:
@eyeownyew wrote:

Protip: Google is your best friend.

Guessing you have to make a shell file or set your environment variables. Either way – I’m sure someone on stackoverflow has had the exact same question

Read full topic

item.title: I need some suggestions
item.dc:creator: @CoreyCobain CoreyCobain
item.description:
@CoreyCobain wrote:

[quote=“arham 4, post:8, topic:530573”][quote author=mrnessie link=topic=649333.msg4363935#msg4363935 date=1379278464]
ok sir! i can even join you on your project, i can help select a base… an teach you to code
[/quote]
PLEASE don’t say PI.[/quote]

Could you possibly tell me how to change the compiler to a mac-compatible format?
I know how to compile using terminal. I just get this error:
“javac: file not found: *.java
Usage: javac
use -help for a list of possible options”

Read full topic

item.title: I need some suggestions
item.dc:creator: @Null_Amount N_A
item.description:
@Null_Amount wrote:

[quote=“CoreyCobain, post:3, topic:530573”][quote author=Null Amount link=topic=649333.msg4363917#msg4363917 date=1379276366]

  1. Anything you want, really. People are going to tell you to use or not use a source as a beginner, it’s really up to you.
  2. Java tutorials
  3. Whatever you think is most important (perhaps patching bugs, general fixes).
  4. Yes, you can write code offline, changes aren’t visually made to the actual source until you compile it.
    [/quote]

Alright thank you. I’ll begin with the tutorials now.
And I really want to start from scratch. That way I know everything about my server.
I want to learn the ins-and-outs of coding and hope that in a few years I will have created an amazing server for me and my friends. :P[/quote]That’s awesome. You could always start from a “cleaned” source. Delta++ is a pretty clean Delta source, a lot of people recommend Hyperion, Apollo, or RuneSource but they require a lot of effort (but considering that you want to start from scratch, they could be good choices for you).

Read full topic

item.title: I need some suggestions
item.dc:creator: @CoreyCobain CoreyCobain
item.description:
@CoreyCobain wrote:

[quote=“Null Amount, post:2, topic:530573”]1. Anything you want, really. People are going to tell you to use or not use a source as a beginner, it’s really up to you.
2. Java tutorials
3. Whatever you think is most important (perhaps patching bugs, general fixes).
4. Yes, you can write code offline, changes aren’t visually made to the actual source until you compile it.[/quote]

Alright thank you. I’ll begin with the tutorials now.
And I really want to start from scratch. That way I know everything about my server.
I want to learn the ins-and-outs of coding and hope that in a few years I will have created an amazing server for me and my friends.

EDIT: If you could point me in the direction of tutorial on how to start a server from scratch, that would be awesome.

Read full topic

item.title: I need some suggestions
item.dc:creator: @Null_Amount N_A
item.description:
@Null_Amount wrote:

[quote=“CoreyCobain, post:1, topic:530573”]I want to begin coding my own rsps.
I’ve done nothing more than setting up an already-made server and got it running.
Now I want to see what would be a good starting point for creating a wonderful server.

I would like to know the following things:
What’s a good source to start with?
What are some “must-study” tutorials found on this website?
What should I start coding first?
Can I code offline, then release the update once I’m online?

I’m on a Mac. OSX 10.8.[/quote]

  1. Anything you want, really. People are going to tell you to use or not use a source as a beginner, it’s really up to you.
  2. Java tutorials
  3. Whatever you think is most important (perhaps patching bugs, general fixes).
  4. Yes, you can write code offline, changes aren’t visually made to the actual source until you compile it.

Read full topic
